Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Modeling Infectious Diseases: How Much Ecological Complexity Must We Address?
Award.AbstractNarration:
Ecology of Infectious Disease Special Competition - Spring 2011

Ecological systems are undeniably complex. Evaluating the appropriate level of complexity needed to fully understand their dynamics is essential to more efficiently increase the predictive accuracy of models. With funding through this Grant, this theoretical and empirical research will analyze the benefits of added complexity in host-parasite models and the extent to which including complexity increases the predictive accuracy of dynamical models. The team from the University of California-Santa Barbara and Princeton University will examine the role played by parasites in food webs for 16 estuarine systems along a latitudinal gradient of the Pacific coast of North America. They will model four focal parasites found in these webs and perform laboratory and field studies to parameterize the model. Versions of these models will vary in aspects of ecological complexity, including alternative hosts, other parasites, varying detail about life stages, direct and indirect effects of non-hosts and temperature.

The study is innovative and certainly worth of funding. The research will advance understanding of how model performance changes with added complexity and investigate the level of detail needed to address life-stage complexity, alternative host diversity and food web complexity. Examining how model performance improves with complexity and the cost of including that complexity will provide insight on the most appropriate level of complexity needed for infectious disease models to be most suitably predictive.

The broader impacts of this project are very strong. The research from this study will provide a framework for how to most effectively model infectious diseases in complex systems and will address how parasites impact ecological networks and surrounding biodiversity. This project will make excellent provision for the training and support of a post-doctoral researcher, graduate students and undergraduates, including individuals from under-represented groups. This study will also feature excellent and very appropriate outreach to K-12 teachers and students and will enhance international scientific collaboration through interaction with scientists and students from Mexico, Czech Republic, Argentina and Australia.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit

While putting parasites in food webs, we made several discoveries. We found mites living in the eye orbits of a cormorant, where others had not looked. We discovered and are describing a new species of ciliate pathogen in one of the most common West Coast crabs. We documented that an invasive snail brought a blood fluke from New Zealand to Europe. We found that the striped shore crab is an intraguild predator on a snail that is an important host for many trematode parasites. We looked for, but did not find, competition between parasites that manipulate host behavior. We documented substantial differences in the levels of tapeworm parasitism in Arctic charr and brown trout that likely reflect age- and species-level differences in the food web interactions of these hosts. We found that increased snail density can benefit parasite recruitment, while simultaneously reducing per-capita host infection risk. Thus snails have safety in numbers even while parasites benefit from dense snail patches. In this same system, we found that competition-colonization tradeoffs help explain the coexistence of 20 parasite species that infect the same snail species, but that other factors must play a role. These results bear on the ecology of infectious disease, and more broadly to community ecology, which often invokes competition-colonization tradeoffs to explain species diversity.

 

We also learned some things about how human-induced environmental change can alter host-parasite systems. In trying to learn from the past, we found pre-historic sea-level change has driven changes in the location and amount of estuarine habitat on the West Coast, including the probable existence of estuarine refugia 20,000 years ago and the subsequent genetic mixing of fish species as estuarine habitat expanded following the rise in sea level. By modeling future sea level rise, we learned that the endangered Belding’s Savannah Sparrow will be extirpated from most populations within 100 years if no major management action is taken. Parasites will also suffer. For instance, a reversed latitudinal gradient for the guild of trematodes infecting horn snails suggests climate change might reduce parasite diversity. Hump shaped temperature performance curves for trematode larvae further shows how realistic high temperatures can negatively impact parasites. Analyzing a series of “digital” consumer-resource networks and empirical networks of parasites of vertebrate hosts, we documented that ecological networks that are robust under historical conditions become much less robust under new conditions, such as those that occur with anthropogenic changes, One anthropogenic change we considered in detail was fishing and aquaculture, finding that marine diseases have substantial economic and environmental impacts. Disease is a substantial negative externality of aquaculture and a barrier to its profitability.

 

Although we focus on estuarine food webs we also include other ecosystems. For instance, we discovered a surprisingly high diversity of trematode parasites that are highly connected to the food web in what is otherwise a species-poor sub-Arctic lake community. We constructed food webs including parasites for different aquatic ecosystems around the world, finding parasites alter food-web structure in unique ways, given their close physical intimacy with their hosts, complex life cycles, and small body sizes. Predator-parasite links are common and have unique structures in food webs. Parasites constituted up to 40% of the total prey links of predators, and each parasite had, on average, between 4 and 14 predators. Trophically transmitted parasites used 44-79% of the links for transmission to their down-stream hosts, indicating how intensively food webs are used by parasites.

 

Finally, our efforts involved creating new theory. We created a general consumer-resource population dynamical model that unifies all types of classical consumer-resource interactions, including all types of infectious agent-host interactions. We also constructed theory for the total abundance, biomass, and energy flux of parasites inside of hosts, based on body size and metabolic scaling. Initial empirical tests indicate that energetic resources ultimately limit parasite load, and that the theory has great promise to help us understand and predict parasite load in a wide range of hosts.

 

Broader impacts

This project involved training/mentoring/hiring of more than 5 post-docs (4 female, 1 Latina), 14 PhD students (4 Latino/a, 1 Asian, 11 female), 4 Masters students (3 female, 2 Latina), 4 full-time research technicians (2 of which left to undertake graduate school), and 121 undergraduates, including individuals belonging to a wide range of underrepresented groups, all of whom were actively engaged with the research.
